bestBHT.bht: Believers are commanded to not overestimate themselves but to have a humble and sober judgment of their own abilities. Their measure of faith, a gift from God, introduces them to new standards of measurement. Through this faith, they accurately determine the extent of their powers without thinking too highly of themselves. Pride is equated with a form of insanity, and recognizing the diversity of gifts among believers promotes humility. By acknowledging that all gifts come from God, individuals can develop a wise and grateful mindset.

Henry Alford: I say, a mild expression for ‘I command;’ enforced as a command by the following words, through the grace given to me.
He says it not to this person or that person only, but to ruler and ruled, to bond and free, to simple and wise, to woman and man.
His measure of faith is his receptivity of graces of the Spirit, itself no inherent congruity, but the gift and apportionment of God.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: not to be high-minded above what he ought to be minded, but so to be minded as to be sober-minded
Faith is here viewed as the inlet to all the other graces
as God hath given to each his particular capacity to take in the gifts and graces which He designs for the general good
Albert Barnes: Not to over-estimate himself, or to think more of himself than he ought to...by their Christian attainments.
There is no way to maintain a wise and proper conduct so certain, as to form a humble and modest estimate of our own character.

We are not, therefore, to be elated in our view of ourselves; we are not to judge of our own characters by wealth, or talent, or learning, but by our attachment to God, and by the influence of faith on our minds.
Marvin Vincent: The point of the passage is a warning against an undue self-estimate, and a corresponding exhortation to estimate one's self with discrimination and sober judgment.
The character of this measure or standard is determined by faith.

Faith, in introducing him into God's kingdom, introduces him to new standards of measurement, according to which he accurately determines the nature and extent of his powers, and so does not think of himself too highly.
John Calvin: I speak not of myself; but, as God’s ambassador, I bring to you the commands which he has entrusted to me.
He draws us away from the investigation of those things which can bring nothing but harassment to the mind, and no edification.
It is a part of our reasonable sacrifice to surrender ourselves, in a meek and teachable spirit, to be ruled and guided by God.
Philip Schaff: The special requirement which he is now to make serves in fact by way of confirmation to the general exhortation.
Not to think of himself...but to be so minded as to be sober-minded.
The aim of one’s self-knowledge should be wise discretion. Practically self-esteem leads to indiscretion.
Archibald T. Robertson: Self-conceit is here treated as a species of insanity.
A measure of faith...Each has his gift from God. There is no occasion for undue pride.
John Gill: Not to think [of himself] more highly than he ought to think.
Such ought to consider that what gifts, abilities, light, and knowledge they have, they have then, not of themselves, but from God.
That they have not all faith, and all knowledge, or do not know the whole of the faith of the Gospel only a measure of it, which is dealt out, divided, and parted to every man.
John Wesley: Through the grace which is given to me - He modestly adds this, lest he should seem to forget his own direction.
To every one that is among you - Believers at Rome. Happy, had they always remembered this!
The measure of faith - Treated of in the first and following chapters, from which all other gifts and graces flow.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 12:3, the apostle Paul emphasizes the need for believers to have a proper self-assessment and not think too highly of themselves. By commanding this, he encourages a humble mindset for all individuals regardless of their social status or gender. Recognizing that faith is the key to unlock other spiritual graces, Paul reminds believers that their measure of faith is a gift from God. The aim is to prevent self-conceit, which is akin to a form of insanity, and to approach self-evaluation with sober judgment. This measure of faith, given to each person by God, should lead to gratitude and a recognition of the diversity of gifts among believers. Ultimately, this passage serves as a warning against pride and an exhortation to view oneself with humility and wisdom.

In this verse, believers are urged to not think too highly of themselves but to approach self-evaluation with sober judgment. The measure of faith they possess is a gift from God and serves as an introduction to new standards of measurement. Pride and self-conceit are seen as forms of insanity that hinder spiritual growth. By recognizing that their gifts come from God and that there is diversity among believers, individuals can cultivate a humble and wise mindset. Ultimately, this encourages gratitude and an accurate understanding of one's own abilities.

Believers are commanded to not overestimate themselves but to have a humble and sober judgment of their own abilities. Their measure of faith, a gift from God, introduces them to new standards of measurement. Through this faith, they accurately determine the extent of their powers without thinking too highly of themselves. Pride is equated with a form of insanity, and recognizing the diversity of gifts among believers promotes humility. By acknowledging that all gifts come from God, individuals can develop a wise and grateful mindset.

In Romans 12:3, believers are urged to have a sober mindset and not think too highly of themselves. The measure of faith they possess is a gift from God, introducing them to new standards of measurement for their abilities. Paul warns against pride and self-conceit, treating them as forms of insanity. Instead, believers should acknowledge the diversity of their gifts and the fact that these gifts come from God. This encourages a humble and grateful attitude, accurate self-evaluation, and wise discretion.

Believers are cautioned against conceit and reminded to evaluate themselves with sobriety. The measure of faith each person possesses is a gift from God, granting access to other spiritual graces. True self-assessment comes through recognizing the diversity of gifts among believers and understanding that they are bestowed by God. Pride is likened to insanity and should be avoided. Embracing humility and gratitude allows individuals to accurately assess their own abilities and exercise wise discretion while acknowledging the source of their gifts.
